question:
Which of the following personalities had the key role in fighting against the British East India Company in the Battle of Porto Novo?

SSC MTS 28/10/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Battle of Porto Novo was fought on 1 July 1781 between the British East India Company and the forces of Hyder Ali, the Sultan of Mysore.
  • The battle took place near Porto Novo (present-day Parangipettai) in Tamil Nadu.
  • Hyder Ali led the Mysore army, while the British forces were commanded by Sir Eyre Coote.

Key Highlights:

  • Despite Hyder Ali’s larger army, the British emerged victorious due to superior tactics and discipline.
  • This battle was part of the Second Anglo-Mysore War (1780–1784).
  • Hyder Ali played a crucial role in resisting British expansion in South India and allied with the French against the British.

Additional Information:

  • Maharaja Ranjit Singh was a Sikh ruler in North India and had no connection with the Southern wars or the Battle of Porto Novo.
  • Alamgir II was a Mughal emperor (1754–1759), but not involved in this battle.
  • Gopala Nayaker was a regional leader in Tamil Nadu but did not play a role in the Battle of Porto Novo.

question:
Which of the following battles is considered the formal beginning of the British Raj in India?

SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Battle of Plassey (fought on 23 June 1757) is widely regarded as the formal beginning of British political rule in India.
  • It was fought between the British East India Company led by Robert Clive and the Nawab of Bengal, Siraj-ud-Daulah.

Key Highlights:

  • The battle resulted in the defeat of Siraj-ud-Daulah, primarily due to betrayal by Mir Jafar, his commander.
  • The victory gave the British control over Bengal, the richest province at the time.
  • This enabled the East India Company to:
    • Collect revenue from Bengal
    • Build a military base
    • Interfere in regional politics

Additional Information:

  • Battle of Buxar (1764) – Strengthened British control; led to Diwani rights over Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa.
  • Battle of Wandiwash (1760) – Decisive British victory over the French in South India.
  • First Carnatic War (1746–48) – Early Anglo-French rivalry in South India, not directly linked to British Raj.

question:
In which year was the Battle of Buxar fought?

SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Battle of Buxar was fought on 23 October 1764 between the British East India Company and the combined forces of:
    • Mir Qasim (Nawab of Bengal),
    • Shah Alam II (Mughal Emperor),
    • and Shuja-ud-Daula (Nawab of Awadh).

Key Highlights:

  • The British forces were led by Hector Munro.
  • The British won decisively, leading to their dominance in the eastern region of India.
  • It was more significant than the Battle of Plassey in establishing British political and administrative control.

Aftermath:

  • The Treaty of Allahabad (1765) was signed, under which:
    • The British East India Company received Diwani rights (revenue collection) for Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa from the Mughal emperor.
    • This marked the real beginning of British territorial rule in India.

Additional Information:

  • 1757 – Battle of Plassey
  • 1764 – Battle of Buxar
  • 1777 and 1793 – Not related to major battles establishing British rule

question:
Where was the first jute mill set up in India?

SSC CHSL 04/08/2023 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The first jute mill in India was established in Rishra, West Bengal, in the year 1855.
  • It was located along the Hugli River, near Kolkata, and marked the beginning of organized jute industry in India.

Key Highlights:

  • Founded by George Acland, who brought jute spinning machinery from Dundee (Scotland).
  • The location was ideal due to:
    • Proximity to raw jute from the Bengal region
    • Availability of water transport via the Hugli River
    • Cheap labor and port facilities in Kolkata
  • This mill laid the foundation for India’s jute export industry, which later flourished in British colonial trade.

Additional Information:

  • Mumbai – Center for cotton textile industry.
  • Chennai – Known for leather and automobile industries.
  • Haryana – Not associated with the early jute industry.

question:
Which of the following modern industries were in operation in India during the British Rule?

a. Cotton

b. Jute

c. Iron and Steel

SSC CGL 24/07/2023 (1st Shift)
option_1: (a) All of a, b and c
option_2: Both a and b
solution:
• During the British rule in India, several modern industries were established, especially by the second half of the 19th century and early 20th century.

Key Industries in Operation:

  • Cotton Industry:
    • One of the earliest industries.
    • First cotton mill: Bombay (Mumbai), 1854.
    • Grew rapidly in Mumbai and Ahmedabad.
  • Jute Industry:
    • First jute mill: Rishra (West Bengal), 1855.
    • Flourished along the Hugli River.
    • India became a major exporter of jute products.
  • Iron and Steel Industry:
    • TISCO (Tata Iron and Steel Company) was established in 1907 at Jamshedpur.
    • Marked the beginning of heavy industries in India.

Thus, all three industries—cotton, jute, and iron & steel—were operational during British rule.

Additional Information:

  • These industries were developed mainly for British economic interests, such as supplying raw materials and finished goods.
  • Indian industrialists like Jamsetji Tata played key roles despite colonial restrictions.

question:
In the 18th century, the development of cotton industries in Britain resulted in _________.

SSC MTS 02/05/2023 (Morning)
option_1: Increase in demand of Indian textile in Britain
option_2: Decline of textiles production in India
option_3: Increase in demand of Indian textile in India
option_4: Decline of British textiles industries in India
solution:
• In the 18th century, the Industrial Revolution in Britain led to the rise of mechanized cotton textile industries.
  • British manufacturers now produced textiles cheaper and faster using machines, especially after inventions like the Spinning Jenny and Power Loom.

Impact on India:

  • India was historically known for its fine handwoven cotton textiles (e.g., muslin, chintz).
  • However, with mass production in Britain, Indian handmade textiles couldn’t compete in price or volume.
  • The British imposed high tariffs and duties on Indian textiles entering Britain while allowing British textiles free access to Indian markets.

As a result:

  • Indian weavers and artisans suffered.
  • There was a sharp decline in textile production in India, marking a major setback for the traditional Indian textile industry.

Additional Information:

  • This shift turned India from a textile exporter to a raw cotton supplier.
  • Many skilled artisans lost livelihoods, accelerating de-industrialization under British rule.

question:
In 1600, the East India Company acquired a charter from _________.

SSC MTS 18/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• In the year 1600, the British East India Company was granted a charter by Queen Elizabeth I.
  • The charter was issued on 31 December 1600, giving the company exclusive rights to trade in the East Indies (Asia, mainly India and Southeast Asia).

Key Points:

  • This charter allowed the company to:
    • Monopolize trade with the East
    • Establish trading posts and settlements
    • Build ships and fortifications
  • The company later expanded its influence in India through:
    • Trade in spices, cotton, silk, indigo, saltpetre
    • Formation of factories in Surat, Madras, Bombay, and Calcutta
    • Eventually intervening in Indian politics and establishing British rule

Additional Information:

  • Queen Victoria came to power much later (1837) and became Empress of India in 1876.
  • King Edward VI and King Henry IV ruled before the 17th century and were not involved in this event.

question:
The first English factory was set up on the banks of the river _______ in 1651.

SSC CHSL 13/03/2023 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The first English factory (trading post) in India was established in 1651 by the British East India Company on the banks of the Hugli River (also spelled Hooghly) in Bengal.
  • This was set up at Hugli town, near Calcutta (now Kolkata).

Key Highlights:

  • The factory began as a trading warehouse with permission from the local Mughal authorities.
  • It marked the start of British commercial presence in eastern India.
  • Over time, this location expanded and led to the foundation of Fort William and the city of Calcutta.

Additional Information:

  • The English gradually acquired zamindari rights and built fortifications.
  • The Hugli River provided excellent trade access for ships, making it a key strategic location.
  • Other rivers listed (Son, Yamuna, Ganga) were not where the first English factory was built.

question:
Which of the following pairs is correct regarding the East India Company army?

I. Sawar — Men on horses

II. Musket — A heavy gun used by infantry soldiers

SSC CHSL 17/03/2023 (3rd Shift)
option_3: Both I and II
option_4: Neither I nor II
solution:
Let’s examine both statements about the East India Company’s army:

I. Sawar — Men on horses

  • Correct: The term "Sawar" (also spelled "Sowar") refers to cavalry soldiers or mounted troops—i.e., soldiers who fought on horseback.
  • It was a common term used in Indian and British Indian armies to denote horsemen.

II. Musket — A heavy gun used by infantry soldiers

  • Correct: A musket is a long, heavy firearm that was used by infantry soldiers before modern rifles were developed.
  • Muskets were single-shot, muzzle-loaded guns, commonly used in the 17th to 19th centuries.

  • Both statements are correct, hence the correct answer is:

question:
The British East India Company captured Pondicherry (Puducherry) from the French in the year ______.

SSC CGL 11/04/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• The British East India Company captured Pondicherry (now Puducherry) from the French in the year 1761 during the Third Carnatic War.
  • This was part of the larger global conflict known as the Seven Years' War (1756–1763).

Key Points:

  • Pondicherry was the capital of French possessions in India.
  • In 1761, the British launched a successful military campaign, capturing and destroying Pondicherry to break French dominance in South India.
  • However, Pondicherry was returned to the French after the Treaty of Paris in 1763, though their influence significantly diminished.

Additional Information:

  • 1674 – The French East India Company established its presence in Pondicherry.
  • 1699 and 1738 – Not directly related to the capture of Pondicherry.
  • The capture in 1761 marked a key British victory over the French in India.

question:
Which monument was built in 1924 to welcome King George V and Queen Mary?

SSC CHSL 15/04/2021 (Morning)
solution:
• The Gateway of India was built in 1924 in Mumbai (then Bombay) to commemorate the visit of King George V and Queen Mary to India in 1911.
  • Although the royal visit took place in 1911, the foundation stone was laid in 1913, and the construction was completed in 1924.

Key Features:

  • Located on the waterfront in South Mumbai, overlooking the Arabian Sea.
  • Designed by George Wittet in Indo-Saracenic style.
  • The structure later also became symbolic as the point from where the British troops departed India in 1948, marking the end of colonial rule.

Other Options:

  • Bombay Castle – A much older Portuguese-built structure, later used by the British.
  • Victoria Memorial – Built in Kolkata in memory of Queen Victoria (completed in 1921).
  • Chattri Brighton – A memorial in the UK for Indian soldiers who died in WWI, not related to King George V’s visit.

question: Which European power was defeated by the British in the Battle of Wandiwash (1760)?
solution:
• The Battle of Wandiwash was fought in 1760 between the British East India Company and the French East India Company.
  • It was a decisive battle during the Third Carnatic War (part of the global Seven Years’ War).

Key Highlights:

  • The British forces were led by Sir Eyre Coote.
  • The French were commanded by Thomas Arthur, Comte de Lally.
  • The British defeated the French, capturing key French officers and territories.

Outcome:

  • Marked the end of French colonial ambitions in India.
  • The British emerged as the dominant European power in India.
  • This victory paved the way for British political control over large parts of India.

Additional Information:

  • The Treaty of Paris (1763) formally ended the Seven Years’ War and restored some French territories, but their political influence in India was lost.

question: The Battle of Buxar (1764) was fought between the British and which alliance?
option_1: Mughal emperor, Nawab of Awadh, Nawab of Bengal
solution:
• The Battle of Buxar was fought on 22 October 1764 between the British East India Company and a triple alliance of:
    • Shah Alam II – the Mughal Emperor
    • Shuja-ud-Daula – the Nawab of Awadh
    • Mir Qasim – the Nawab of Bengal (deposed)

Key Highlights:

  • The British forces were led by Hector Munro.
  • The Indian alliance was decisively defeated, marking a turning point in British expansion in India.
  • After this battle, the British secured Diwani rights (right to collect revenue) of Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa through the Treaty of Allahabad (1765).

Impact:

  • It established the British East India Company as a major power in India.
  • Unlike the Battle of Plassey (1757), which was more of a conspiracy, the Battle of Buxar was a full military engagement.

Additional Information:

  • This battle confirmed the decline of Mughal authority.
  • It gave the British both military power and financial control in large parts of India.

question: Who introduced the policy of Subsidiary Alliance in India?
solution:
• The Subsidiary Alliance was a diplomatic strategy used by the British East India Company to establish control over Indian princely states without direct annexation.
  • This policy was introduced by Lord Wellesley in 1798 during his tenure as the Governor-General of India (1798–1805).
  • Under this alliance, Indian rulers had to accept British forces within their territory and pay for their maintenance.
  • In return, they were assured protection from internal and external threats.
  • They also had to exclude all European rivals and seek British permission before entering any alliances.

Additional Information:

  • The first Indian state to sign the Subsidiary Alliance was Hyderabad in 1798.
  • This policy weakened the sovereignty of Indian rulers and expanded British control indirectly.
  • It was one of the key tools used by the British for imperial expansion prior to full annexation policies like Doctrine of Lapse.

question: Under the Subsidiary Alliance, Indian rulers had to:
option_1: Accept British residents and disband their armies
option_2: Surrender their lands permanently
solution:
• The Subsidiary Alliance policy required Indian rulers to accept a British Resident (official representative) in their court.
  • They had to disband their own standing armies and depend on British forces for protection.
  • Rulers were also forbidden from forming alliances with any other power or waging wars without British consent.
  • This ensured complete political control of the British over the native rulers while avoiding direct annexation.

Additional Information:

  • The ruler had to pay a subsidy (maintenance cost) for the stationed British troops.
  • If the subsidy was not paid, part of the state territory was taken by the British.
  • This policy was introduced by Lord Wellesley and first accepted by Hyderabad in 1798.

question: Which Governor-General is associated with the policy of Doctrine of Lapse?
solution:
• The Doctrine of Lapse was a policy implemented by Lord Dalhousie, who served as the Governor-General of India from 1848 to 1856.
  • According to this doctrine, if a ruler of a princely state died without a natural male heir, his kingdom would be annexed by the British.
  • Adopted sons were not recognized as legitimate successors under this policy.
  • This policy was used to annex several Indian states, such as Satara (1848), Jhansi (1853), and Nagpur (1854).

Additional Information:

  • The policy caused widespread resentment among Indian rulers and was one of the key causes of the Revolt of 1857.
  • Rani Lakshmibai of Jhansi strongly opposed this policy, as her adopted son was denied succession.

question: According to the Doctrine of Lapse, the British could annex a state if:
option_1: The ruler refused to pay taxes
option_2: The ruler was over 70 years of age
option_3: There was no natural heir
option_4: The ruler opposed British reforms
solution:
• Under the Doctrine of Lapse, a princely state could be annexed by the British East India Company if the ruling king died without a natural male heir.
  • The policy did not recognize adopted sons as legitimate successors.
  • This doctrine was implemented by Lord Dalhousie during his tenure as Governor-General (1848–1856).
  • It provided the British with a legal pretext to absorb many Indian states into the empire.

Additional Information:

  • States annexed under this doctrine included Satara (1848), Sambalpur (1850), Jhansi (1853), and Nagpur (1854).
  • This policy increased mistrust and hostility towards the British among Indian rulers.
  • The annexation of Jhansi led to Rani Lakshmibai’s rebellion in 1857, making her a key figure in the revolt.

question: Which of the following states was not annexed under the Doctrine of Lapse?
solution:
• The Doctrine of Lapse was applied to annex princely states where the ruler died without a natural male heir, and adopted sons were not recognized as successors.
  • Jhansi, Nagpur, and Satara were all annexed under this doctrine by Lord Dalhousie.
  • However, Awadh (Oudh) was not annexed under the Doctrine of Lapse.
  • Instead, Awadh was annexed in 1856 on the grounds of misgovernance and maladministration, not due to lack of an heir.

Additional Information:

  • The annexation of Awadh further inflamed tensions and contributed to the Revolt of 1857.
  • The Nawab of Awadh at the time was Wajid Ali Shah, who protested his removal.
  • Awadh’s annexation was seen as a betrayal, especially by its large sepoy population in the British army.

question: Who was the Governor-General during the annexation of Awadh in 1856?
solution:
• The annexation of Awadh (Oudh) took place in 1856 under the pretext of misgovernance and maladministration.
  • This annexation was carried out by Lord Dalhousie, who was the Governor-General of India from 1848 to 1856.
  • Unlike previous annexations under the Doctrine of Lapse, Awadh had a legitimate heir, so it was annexed not due to lack of succession, but due to alleged bad governance.
  • This move sparked widespread anger, especially among the sepoys (soldiers), many of whom were recruited from Awadh.

Additional Information:

  • The Nawab of Awadh at the time, Wajid Ali Shah, was dethroned and exiled to Calcutta.
  • The annexation of Awadh became one of the key flashpoints that contributed to the Revolt of 1857.
  • Lord Dalhousie is associated with both the Doctrine of Lapse and the Awadh annexation policy.

question: The Carnatic Wars were fought between:
solution:
• The Carnatic Wars were a series of three military conflicts fought in South India between the British East India Company and the French East India Company.
  • These wars occurred during the 18th century (from 1746 to 1763) and were part of the larger struggle for colonial dominance.
  • The wars were named after the Carnatic region in southern India where most of the battles took place.
  • Ultimately, the British emerged victorious, ending French political influence in India.

Additional Information:

  • First Carnatic War (1746–1748) – Associated with the War of Austrian Succession in Europe.
  • Second Carnatic War (1749–1754) – Involved internal succession disputes supported by French and British forces.
  • Third Carnatic War (1756–1763) – Linked with the Seven Years' War; ended with the Treaty of Paris (1763), confirming British dominance.
  • Key Figures: British – Robert Clive, French – Joseph François Dupleix and Count de Lally.

question: Which Indian ruler is known for resisting British expansion in Mysore?
solution:
• Haider Ali, the ruler of Mysore, is well known for his strong resistance against British expansion in South India during the 18th century.
  • He was a brilliant military commander and challenged the British East India Company in the Anglo-Mysore Wars.
  • He modernized the Mysorean army with the help of French military techniques.
  • Haider Ali fought especially in the First (1767–69) and Second (1780–84) Anglo-Mysore Wars.

Additional Information:

  • His son, Tipu Sultan, continued this resistance after Haider Ali’s death and became an iconic figure in the struggle against British rule.
  • The Second Anglo-Mysore War was notable for several British defeats, including the Battle of Pollilur (1780) where Haider Ali defeated British forces.
  • Haider Ali maintained diplomatic relations with the French, Marathas, and Nizam to counterbalance British power.

question: Tipu Sultan died fighting in which Anglo-Mysore war?
solution:
• Tipu Sultan, also known as the Tiger of Mysore, died during the Fourth Anglo-Mysore War.
  • This war took place in 1799, and it marked the final conflict between the British East India Company and the Kingdom of Mysore under Tipu's leadership.
  • The war ended with the storming of Srirangapatna, Tipu’s capital, by British forces.
  • Tipu Sultan was killed in battle while defending his fort, making him one of the most prominent Indian rulers to die fighting the British.

Additional Information:

  • The Fourth Anglo-Mysore War was fought between Tipu Sultan and the British forces led by Lord Wellesley.
  • Tipu’s death marked the end of Mysore’s resistance against British domination.
  • After his death, Mysore was partially annexed, and the remaining territory was handed over to the Wodeyar dynasty under British control.

question: Who was the first Governor-General of Bengal?
solution:
• The first Governor-General of Bengal was Warren Hastings, appointed in 1773 under the Regulating Act of 1773.
  • Before this, the position was known as Governor of Bengal, held by figures like Robert Clive.
  • Hastings' role was significant in laying the foundations of British administration in India, particularly in Bengal.
  • He established strong control over the civil administration, revenue system, and judiciary.

Additional Information:

  • Warren Hastings served from 1773 to 1785.
  • He faced impeachment proceedings in Britain after his return, led by Edmund Burke, but was eventually acquitted.
  • His reforms included codifying Hindu and Muslim laws, restructuring revenue collection, and introducing civil courts.

question: The Regulating Act of 1773 was passed to:
option_1: Improve trade in Bengal
option_3: Control East India Company’s administration
solution:
• The Regulating Act of 1773 was the first major step by the British Parliament to regulate the affairs of the East India Company in India.
  • Its primary objective was to bring the Company’s administrative and financial operations under British government control.
  • It led to the creation of the post of Governor-General of Bengal, and Warren Hastings became the first to hold this position.
  • It also established a Supreme Court in Calcutta to oversee legal matters.

Additional Information:

  • The Act marked the beginning of Parliamentary control over the Company.
  • It created an executive council of four members to assist the Governor-General.
  • However, the Act had several flaws, leading to further acts like the Pitt’s India Act of 1784.

question: The Permanent Settlement was introduced by:
solution:
• The Permanent Settlement was introduced in 1793 by Lord Cornwallis, who was then the Governor-General of Bengal.
  • This system was aimed at streamlining land revenue collection by the British East India Company.
  • Under it, zamindars (landlords) were made the hereditary owners of land and were responsible for collecting and paying a fixed revenue to the Company.
  • The settlement was "permanent", meaning the tax amount would not be increased in the future, regardless of agricultural output.

Additional Information:

  • Implemented mainly in Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa.
  • While it ensured stable income for the Company, it led to exploitation of peasants, as zamindars often collected excessive rent.
  • Many zamindars lost their lands if they failed to pay the fixed revenue on time.

question: Who among the following resisted British expansion in Punjab?
solution:
• Maharaja Ranjit Singh was the powerful ruler of the Sikh Empire in Punjab and is known for resisting British expansion in the region.
  • He successfully maintained the independence of Punjab during his lifetime and signed the Treaty of Amritsar (1809) with the British, which defined boundaries but avoided conflict.
  • Ranjit Singh created a strong, modernized army with European officers and kept the British at bay through diplomacy and military strength.

Additional Information:

  • After his death in 1839, internal conflicts weakened the Sikh Empire.
  • The Anglo-Sikh Wars began soon after, resulting in the annexation of Punjab in 1849 by the British.
  • Maharaja Ranjit Singh is remembered as the "Lion of Punjab" for his leadership and resistance to colonial encroachment.

question: After which battle did the British gain control over Bengal’s administration?
solution:
• The Battle of Buxar was fought in 1764 between the British East India Company and a combined force of Mir Qasim (Nawab of Bengal), Shuja-ud-Daula (Nawab of Awadh), and Shah Alam II (Mughal Emperor).
  • The British, led by Hector Munro, decisively defeated the alliance.
  • This victory gave the British complete political and administrative control over Bengal, going beyond the mere military dominance achieved at Plassey.

Additional Information:

  • After this battle, the Treaty of Allahabad (1765) was signed.
  • Under this treaty, the Mughal Emperor granted the British the Diwani rights—the right to collect revenue from Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa.
  • This marked the beginning of British administrative rule in India and the transformation from a trading company to a governing power.

question: The Treaty of Allahabad (1765) gave the British which right?
option_1: To annex Indian states
option_2: To collect Diwani of Bengal, Bihar, Orissa
option_4: To disband Indian armies
solution:
• The Treaty of Allahabad (1765) was signed after the British victory in the Battle of Buxar (1764).
  • This treaty was between Robert Clive (on behalf of the East India Company) and Mughal Emperor Shah Alam II.
  • Under the treaty, the Mughal emperor granted the Diwani rights to the British East India Company.
  • Diwani rights meant the right to collect revenue and administer civil justice in Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa.

Additional Information:

  • This treaty marked the beginning of British economic control over eastern India.
  • The Mughal emperor, in return, received an annual pension.
  • It established the dual government system—British collected revenue, but Indian rulers handled administration nominally.

question: The Anglo-Maratha wars ended with:
solution:
• The Anglo-Maratha Wars were a series of three wars fought between the British East India Company and the Maratha Empire.
  • The wars ended effectively with the Treaty of Bassein (1802), signed between Peshwa Baji Rao II and the British.
  • Under this treaty, the Peshwa accepted British suzerainty and agreed to maintain a British subsidiary force, marking the decline of Maratha power.
  • This treaty paved the way for the Second Anglo-Maratha War and ultimately led to the collapse of Maratha independence.

Additional Information:

  • The Third Anglo-Maratha War (1817–1818) resulted in the final defeat of the Marathas and the annexation of their territories by the British.
  • After this, the British became the paramount power in India, ending the Maratha Confederacy's rule.
  • The Treaty of Salbai (1782) was earlier and ended the First Anglo-Maratha War without decisive gains.

question: Which was the last major Indian territory annexed before 1857?
solution:
• The last major Indian territory to be annexed by the British before the Revolt of 1857 was Awadh (Oudh).
  • It was annexed in 1856 by Lord Dalhousie, not under the Doctrine of Lapse, but on the grounds of maladministration.
  • The Nawab of Awadh, Wajid Ali Shah, was accused of misgoverning and was deposed and exiled to Calcutta.

Additional Information:

  • The annexation of Awadh caused deep resentment, especially among the sepoys of the British Indian Army, many of whom were recruited from the region.
  • It was one of the direct causes of the Revolt of 1857, as it hurt the sentiments of both soldiers and civilians.
  • This annexation marked the final major expansion of British territory before the outbreak of the First War of Independence.
